chunks.original_text: 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪。 为天下溪，常德不离，复归於婴儿。 雄，先之属。 雌，后之属也。 知为天下之先也，必后也，是以圣人后其身而身先也。 溪不求物而物自归之，婴兄不用智而合自然之智。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式。 式，模则也。 为天下式，常德不忒， 忒，差也。 复归於无极。 不可穷也。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷。 为天下谷，常德乃足，复归於朴。 此三者，言常反终后乃德全其所处也。 下章云反者道之动也，功不可取，常处其母也。 朴散则为器，圣人用之则为官长， 朴，真也。 真散则百行出，殊类生，若器也。 圣人因其分散，故为之立官长，以善为师，不善为资，移风易俗，复使归於一也。 故大制不割。 大制者，以天下之心为心，故无割也。 二十九章 将欲取天下而为之，吾见其不得已。 天下神器， 神，无形无方也。 器，合成也。 无形以合，故谓之神器也。 不可为也。 为者败之，执者失之。 万物以自然为性，故可因而不可为也，可通而不可执也。 物有常性而造为之，故必败也； 物有往来而执之，故必失矣。 故物或行或随，或歔或吹，或强或羸，或挫或隳。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 凡此诸或，言物事逆顺反覆，不施为执割也。 圣人达自然之至，畅万物之情，故因而不为，顺而不施，除其所以迷，去其所以惑，故心不乱而物性自得之也。 三十章 以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下， 以道佐人主，尚不可以兵强於天下，况人主躬於道者乎？ 其事好还。 为始者务欲立功生事，而有道者务欲还反无为，故云其事好还也。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 大军之后，必有凶年。 言师凶害之物也，无有所济，必有所伤。 贼害人民，残荒田亩，故约荆棘生也。 善有果而己，不敢以取强。 果，犹济也。 言善用师者，趣以济难而已矣，不以兵力取强於天下矣。 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而勿骄， 吾不以师道为尚，不得已而用，何矜骄之有也。 果而不得已，果而勿强。 言用兵虽趣功果济难，然时故不得已当复，用者但当以除暴乱，不遂用果以为强也。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已。 壮，武力暴兴也，喻以兵强於天下者也。 飘风不终朝，骤雨不终日，故暴兴必不道早已也。 三十一章 夫佳兵者不祥之器，物惑恶之，故有道者不处。 君子居则贵左，用兵则贵右。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之，恬澹为上。 胜而不美，而美之者，是乐杀人。 夫乐杀人者，则不可以得志於天下矣。 吉事尚左； 凶事尚右。 偏将军居左，上将军居右，言以丧礼处之。 杀人之众，以悲哀泣之，战胜以丧礼处之。 三十二章 道常无名，天下莫能臣也。 侯王若能守之，万物将自宾。 道无形不系，常不可名，以无名为常，故曰道常无名也。 朴之为物，以无为心也，亦无名，故将得道，莫若守朴。 夫智者可以能臣也，勇者可以武使也，巧者可以事役也，力者可以重任也，朴之为物，愤然不偏，近於无有，故曰莫能臣也。 抱朴为无，不以物累其真，不以欲害其神，则物自宾而道自得也。 天地相合，以降甘露，民莫之令而自均。 言天地相合，则甘露不求而自降； 我守其真性无为，则民不令而自均也。 始制有名，名亦既有。 夫亦将知止，知止所以不始。
chunks.translated_text:
「Knowing the masculine, keeping the feminine,
Is the Way of the world’s stream.

The Way of the world’s stream,
Ever holds virtue true,
Returning to the state of the infant.

The masculine belongs to the first,
The feminine to the last.
Knowing the first as the Way,
The last must follow—
Hence the Sage follows his own body,
Yet his body leads the world.

The stream does not seek things,
Yet things return to it.
The infant does not wield wisdom,
Yet it aligns with the natural wisdom of all.

Knowing the bright, keeping the dark,
Is the Way of the world’s model.

The model is the standard of form.
The Way of the world’s model,
Ever holds virtue unerring—
Unerring means no deviation.
Returning to the state of the Boundless.

The Boundless cannot be exhausted.
Knowing the honor, keeping the shame,
Is the Way of the world’s valley.

The Way of the world’s valley,
Ever holds virtue complete,
Returning to the state of the Uncarved.

These three—
The Way reverses to its end,
Thus virtue attains fullness in its dwelling.

The next chapter says:
*The reversal is the movement of the Dao;*
Its work cannot be claimed,
Ever abiding in its origin.

The Uncarved scatters and becomes vessels;
The Sage uses it and becomes ruler.
The Uncarved—true essence—
When scattered, gives rise to myriad actions,
Distinct types emerge, like vessels.

The Sage follows its natural division,
Thus establishes rulers,
Using the good as teachers,
The not-good as resources,
Transforming customs and mores,
Restoring all to unity.

Hence the great standard is not severed.
The great standard—
Taking the world’s heart as one’s own—
Thus there is no severing.

**Chapter 29**
When one would take the world by force,
I see it as not inevitable.

The world is a divine vessel—
Divine means formless and boundless,
A vessel means a harmonized whole.
Formless yet harmonized,
Thus it is called a divine vessel.

It cannot be forced.
Forcing brings ruin,
Grasping brings loss.
All things take their nature as given,
Thus one may follow it but not force it,
May guide it but not grasp it.
If one creates against its nature,
It must bring ruin;
If one clings to its coming and going,
It must bring loss.

Thus things may flourish or wither,
May rise or fall,
May grow strong or weak,
May be chipped or shattered.
Hence the Sage avoids excess,
Avoids extravagance,
Avoids dominance.

All these *or*s—
Speak of things and affairs
Inverting, obeying, or returning,
Not to be forced or severed by action.

The Sage reaches the utmost of nature,
Unfolds the emotions of all things,
Thus follows without forcing,
Aligns without imposing,
Removes what confuses,
Discards what bewilders,
Hence his heart remains undisturbed
While the nature of things finds its own fulfillment.

**Chapter 30**
To assist the ruler with the Dao,
Is to not use force of arms to subdue the world.
To assist the ruler with the Dao,
Already cannot rely on arms to subdue the world—
How much more so if the ruler himself abides by the Dao!

His affairs delight in returning.
Those who begin with force
Seek to establish deeds and create affairs,
But those who follow the Dao
Seek to return and undo all doing—
Hence it is said: *His affairs delight in returning.*

Where the teacher dwells,
Thorns and brambles grow.
After great armies,
There must be years of calamity.
The teacher is a harmful thing,
Bringing no aid, only injury.
It plunders the people,
Devastates the fields,
Hence it is said: *Where the teacher dwells, thorns and brambles grow.*

The good use the teacher,
Yet do not dare to seize and force.
Seizing means to aid.
The good who use the teacher
Do so only to relieve difficulties—
Not to seize the world with arms.

When seizing, do not boast,
When seizing, do not vaunt,
When seizing, do not be proud—
I do not hold the teacher’s Dao as superior,
Using it only when there is no alternative—
What boasting or pride could there be?

When seizing is inevitable,
When seizing, do not force.
Though arms are used to achieve victory
And relieve difficulties,
The moment is not to be seized
To force the world.

Things grow strong, then age—
This is called *not the Dao*,
And *not the Dao* soon perishes.
Strong means violent force arises,
Illustrating those who use arms to force the world.
A gusting wind does not last a morning,
A sudden rain does not last a day—
Hence violent force must not be the Dao,
And *not the Dao* soon perishes.

**Chapter 31**
Fine arms are not auspicious instruments;
Things are bewildered and hate them,
Thus those who follow the Dao do not dwell upon them.

The gentleman, when at rest, values the left;
When using arms, values the right.
Arms are not auspicious instruments,
Not the tools of the gentleman—
Used only when there is no alternative,
Calmness and moderation are supreme.

Victory yet not glorying in it,
And glorying in victory—
This is to delight in killing.
He who delights in killing
Cannot fulfill his desires in the world.

Auspicious matters honor the left;
Inauspicious matters honor the right.
The Left General is stationed on the left,
The Right General on the right—
Illustrating the treatment with funeral rites.
The multitude of those who kill,
Are to be mourned with sorrowful tears—
Victory is treated with funeral rites.

**Chapter 32**
The Dao is ever nameless,
Yet the world cannot subjugate it.
If lords and kings can guard it,
All things will come as guests of their own accord.

The Dao is formless and does not bind,
Ever nameless—
Taking the nameless as its constant,
Thus it is said: *The Dao is ever nameless.*

The Uncarved, as a thing,
Takes the heart of non-action—
Also nameless.
Thus to attain the Dao,
Nothing is better than guarding the Uncarved.

The wise can subjugate others,
The brave can command force,
The skillful can be employed in tasks,
The strong can be given heavy burdens—
But the Uncarved, as a thing,
Is indignant yet impartial,
Near to nothingness,
Thus it is said: *None can subjugate it.*

Embrace the Uncarved as the nameless,
Do not burden its true nature with things,
Do not harm its divine essence with desires—
Then things will come as guests
And the Dao will be attained.

Heaven and Earth unite,
Descending sweet dew—
The people do not command it,
Yet it is evenly distributed.
Heaven and Earth unite,
Then sweet dew descends without seeking;
I guard its true nature without doing,
Then the people are evenly nourished without command.

At first, the standard had a name,
And the name was already given.
This also is to know when to stop—
Knowing when to stop
Is to not begin.»

chunks.translated_text:
The beginning of governance refers to the time when the Uncarved first became rulers.
When rulers first establish governance, they cannot fail to assign names and define ranks to establish hierarchy, hence the saying: *"The beginning of governance has names."*

Beyond this point, men will contend over trifles—
Thus it is said: *"The names are already given."*
If one knows when to stop,
Then one does not begin.
To persist in naming and commanding things
Is to lose the root of governance—
Thus knowing when to stop is how one avoids ruin.

The Dao in the world is like rivers and valleys in relation to the sea.
Rivers and valleys do not seek the sea,
Yet they naturally flow there without being summoned.
Those who practice the Dao in the world
Do not command yet all is balanced,
Do not seek yet all is attained—
Thus it is said: *"Like rivers and valleys in relation to the sea."*

**Chapter Thirty-Three**
He who knows others is wise,
But he who knows himself is enlightened.
He who knows others is wise—no more.
But he who knows himself stands above wisdom.

He who overcomes others is strong,
But he who overcomes himself is powerful.
He who overcomes others is strong—no more.
But he who overcomes himself loses nothing to diminish his strength.

To apply one’s wisdom to others
Is not as good as applying it to oneself;
To apply one’s strength to others
Is not as good as applying it to oneself.
When wisdom is applied to oneself,
Nothing avoids it;
When strength is applied to oneself,
Nothing can alter it.

He who knows contentment is rich,
For knowing contentment means nothing is lost—
Thus he is rich.

The resolute in action have willpower.
If one is diligent in action, their will must prevail—
Thus it is said: *"The resolute in action have willpower."*

He who does not stray from his path endures.
By self-awareness and measuring one’s strength,
Not straying from his path,
He must attain enduring longevity.

He who dies yet does not perish is long-lived.
Though dead, if the Way of life does not perish,
Then his life is fully preserved.
If the body perishes yet the Dao remains,
How much more so if the body lives and the Dao is not cut short?

**Chapter Thirty-Four**
The Great Dao is vast—
It can be turned left or right.
The Dao is boundless, adapting everywhere,
Turning freely above and below, yet its use knows no limits.

All things rely on it to live yet it does not claim,
Its work is done yet it does not name itself.
It clothes and nourishes all things yet does not lord over them—
Always without desire, it may be called *small*.

All things arise from the Dao yet do not know their source,
Thus the world is always in a state of non-desire,
And all things find their place.
If the Dao does not impose itself on things,
Then it is called *small*.

All things return to it yet it does not rule—
It may be called *great*.
All things return to it to live,
Yet its power makes them unaware of their origin—
This is not small, hence it may also be called *great*.
Because it never seeks to be great,
Thus it achieves greatness.

Greatness lies in the small,
Difficulty lies in the easy.

**Chapter Thirty-Five**
Hold fast to the Great Image,
And the world will come to you.
The Great Image is the mother of all heavenly forms—
Neither cold nor warm, neither cool nor hot,
Thus it can embrace and govern all things without harm.
If the ruler holds to it,
Then the world will come to him.

When they come, they are not harmed,
And peace and stability endure.
Formless, unperceived,
It does not spread or display itself—
Thus all things come to it without obstruction.

Music and bait
Can make passing travelers stop.
The Dao, when spoken of,
Is bland, without taste.
To look at it, it is insufficient;
To listen to it, it is inaudible;
To use it, it is inexhaustible.
This speaks to the Dao’s profundity.

When people hear the words of the Dao,
They prefer music and bait—
What delights the senses in the moment.
Music and bait can make passing travelers stop,
Yet the Dao’s words are bland and tasteless.
To look at it, it does not satisfy the eyes;
To listen to it, it does not please the ears.
If it does not strike the senses,
Yet when used, it cannot be exhausted.

**Chapter Thirty-Six**
To contract, one must first expand;
To weaken, one must first strengthen;
To destroy, one must first establish;
To take away, one must first give—
This is called *subtle clarity*.

To remove the strong and violent,
To eliminate disorder,
One must employ these four methods.
By following the nature of things,
Let them destroy themselves—
No need for harsh punishment to remove what must be removed,
Thus it is called *subtle clarity*.

If one fills their expansion to its fullest
Yet still demands more expansion,
Then all will resist.
If one’s expansion is insufficient
Yet one insists on demanding more,
The more one seeks, the more one endangers oneself.

The soft overcomes the hard.
Fish cannot be dragged from the depths,
And the sharpest tools of state
Should not be displayed to the people.
Sharp tools are what benefit the state.
Yet one must rely on the nature of things,
Not resort to force to govern.
If tools are unseen,
Yet all things find their place,
Then they are the sharpest tools of state.
To display them to the people is to rely on punishment.
Punishment, if used to benefit the state,
Will fail.
Fish dragged from the depths will surely be lost.
To display the sharpest tools of state to the people
Will also surely fail.

**Chapter Thirty-Seven**
The Dao is ever without action,

chunks.original_text: 三十八章 上德不德，是以有德； 下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为而无以为，下德为之而有以为。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有以为。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而扔之。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首。 前识者，道之华而愚之始。 是以大丈夫处其厚不居其薄，处其实不居其华，故去彼取此。 德者，得也。 常得而无丧，利而无害，故以德为名焉。 何以得德？ 由乎道也。 何以尽德？ 以无为用，以无为用则莫不载也。 故物无焉则无物不经，有为则不足以免其生。 是以天地虽广，以无为心； 圣王虽大，以虚为主。 故曰以复而视，则天地之心见； 至日而思之，则先王之至睹也。 故灭其私而无其身，则四海莫不瞻，远近莫不至； 殊其己而有其心，则一体不能自全，肌骨不能相容。 是以上德之人，唯道是用，不德其德，无执无用，故能有德而无不为。 不求而得，不为而成，故虽有德而无德名也。 下德求而得之，为而成之，则立善以治物，故德名有焉。 求而得之，必有失焉。 为而成之，必有败焉。 善名生，则有不善应焉。 故下德为之而有以为也。 无以为者，无所偏为也。 凡不能无为而为之者，皆下德也，仁义礼节是也。 将明德之上下，辄举下德以对上德。 至于无以为极下德下之量，上仁是也。 足及於无以为而犹为之焉，为之而无以为，故有为为之患矣。 本在无为，母在无名，弃本舍母而适其子，功虽大焉，叉有不济。 名虽美焉，伪亦必生。 不能不为而成，不兴而治，则乃为之，故有弘普博施仁爱之者，而爱之无所偏私。 故上仁为之，而无以为也。 爱不能兼，则有抑抗正真而义理之者，忿枉佑直，助彼攻此，物事而有以心为矣。 故上义为之，而有以为也。 直不能笃，则有游饰修文礼敬之者，尚好修敬，校责往来，则不对之间忿怒生焉。 故上礼为之，而莫之应，则攘臂而扔之。 夫大之极也，其唯道乎。 自此已往，岂足尊哉。

**Chapter Thirty-Eight**

The virtue of the highest Dao is not virtue,
And thus it has virtue.
The virtue of the lowly Dao does not lose virtue,
And thus it has no virtue.

The highest virtue acts without action yet nothing is left undone;
The lowly virtue acts and yet has much to do.

The highest benevolence acts yet nothing is left undone;
The highest righteousness acts and yet has much to do.

The highest propriety acts and none respond,
So it forces compliance with raised arms.
Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue arises;
When virtue is lost, benevolence arises;
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
When righteousness is lost, propriety arises.

For propriety is the thinnest layer of loyalty and trust,
And the beginning of chaos.
Preemptive knowledge is the flower of the Dao,
And the origin of folly.

Thus, the noble man dwells in substance, not in superficiality,
In reality, not in ornament—
Hence he discards the latter and embraces the former.

Virtue is that which is obtained.
To always obtain without loss,
To benefit without harm—
Thus it is called *virtue*.

How does one obtain virtue?
Through the Dao.
How does one exhaust virtue?
By acting without action—
Acting without action, nothing is left untransformed.

If there is no action, nothing is left ungoverned;
If there is action, it is insufficient to preserve life.
Thus, though heaven and earth are vast,
Their essence is inaction;
Though sages and kings are great,
Their foundation is emptiness.

Hence it is said:
To return to the origin and observe,
The heart of heaven and earth is revealed;
To ponder it at its zenith,
The profound vision of the ancient kings is attained.

To extinguish self-interest and abandon the ego,
Then the four seas will gaze upon you,
Near and far will come without summoning.
To abandon the self while preserving the heart,
Then not even a single body can remain whole,
Nor can flesh and bone tolerate one another.

Thus, the man of highest virtue
Uses only the Dao,
Does not cling to virtue,
Holds nothing fast—
And so, though he has virtue, he does nothing,
Yet nothing remains undone.
He seeks nothing yet obtains,
Acts yet achieves—
And so, though he has virtue, he bears no name of virtue.

The lowly virtue seeks and obtains,
Acts and achieves—
And so establishes goodness to govern things,
And thus bears the name of virtue.
To seek and obtain is to invite loss;
To act and achieve is to invite ruin.
Good names arise, and evil follows in response.
Thus, the lowly virtue acts and yet has much to do.

To act without preference is to act without partiality.
All who cannot act without action are of the lowly virtue—
Benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and ritual norms.

To illustrate the hierarchy of virtue,
The lowly is contrasted with the highest.
Even when the lowly reaches the extreme of "without action,"
It is still beneath the highest benevolence.
To act while claiming "without action"
Is to invite the calamity of action itself.

The root lies in inaction;
The mother is in the nameless.
To abandon the root and forsake the mother,
Though achievements may be great,
They will not be fulfilled.
Though names may be fair,
Deception will inevitably arise.

Unable to achieve without action,
Unable to govern without exertion—
Then one must act,
And so there are those who widely bestow benevolent love,
Yet love without partiality.

Thus, the highest benevolence acts,
Yet nothing is left undone.
Love cannot be all-encompassing,
So there are those who suppress and oppose,
Who aid the crooked and attack the straight,
Who use things and hearts alike.
Thus, the highest righteousness acts,
And yet has much to do.

Righteousness cannot be steadfast,
So there are those who adorn themselves with ritual,
Who value propriety and respect,
Who scrutinize every exchange—
And so resentment arises where none should be.
Thus, the highest propriety acts,
And none respond,
So it forces compliance with raised arms.

The ultimate is the Dao alone.
From this point onward, what is there to revere?

Thus, even if one’s **virtue** is great and achievements vast,
Wealthy with all things in abundance—
Each still gains its own **virtue**,
Yet cannot fully attain self-sufficiency.

Therefore, Heaven cannot be the **Dao**’s burden,
Earth cannot be its shelter,
Nor can humanity nurture all things.

Though it is honored for its **non-action**,
One cannot abandon **non-action** as its essence.

To abandon **non-action** as its essence,
Then one loses its greatness—
This is called losing the **Dao** and then having **virtue**.

Using **non-action** as a method,
**Virtue** is its mother#1,
So one can act without exertion,
Yet nothing remains unattended.

From this point onward,
One loses the mother of **non-action**.

Unable to value **non-action** yet cherish wide benevolence,
Unable to cherish wide benevolence yet value uprightness,
Unable to value uprightness yet cherish ritual and respect—
This is called losing **virtue** and then having benevolence,
Losing benevolence and then having righteousness,
Losing righteousness and then having propriety.

For propriety begins with insincere loyalty and trust,
And superficial simplicity without depth.
Its censure is only on the surface,
Its subtle intrigues hidden in contention.

Benevolence and righteousness arise from within,
Yet even these are feigned—
How much more so when one labors over outward display and expects it to endure?

Thus, propriety is the thin veneer of loyalty and trust,
And the source of chaos.

The **foreknowledge** of the past
Is knowing what others have known.
It is the rank of lesser **virtue**,
Exhausting one’s wisdom to foresee,
And straining one’s intellect for trivial affairs.
Though **virtue** may seem sincere,
Craft and deceit grow ever more refined;
Though fame may flourish,
It only deepens the loss of true substance.
Laboring yet governing in confusion,
Striving yet bringing corruption—
Even with all the wisdom of the sages,
The people suffer more.

To abandon oneself and follow things,
Then **non-action** prevails and tranquility is achieved.
To cling to simplicity and naturalness,
Then one defies conventional rules and norms.
To take what is gained by others,
And discard what one holds—
This is the superficial understanding of the **Dao**,
And the root of all folly.

Thus, if one attains the **Dao**’s mother of function,
All things act without resistance,
All affairs persist without labor.
Its influence is not seen in form,
Its control is not named—
So benevolence and righteousness may be displayed,
And ritual and respect made manifest.

To bear all upon the **Dao**,
And steady with the **nameless**,
Then nothing is held in higher regard,
No schemes are pursued—
Each abides by its true nature,
Affairs are conducted with sincerity.
Then benevolence is thick with **virtue**,
Righteousness is upright,
And ritual and respect are clear.

To abandon what bears them,
To forsake their origin—
To use their completed forms,
To strain one’s brilliance—
Then benevolence is merely sincere,
Righteousness is but contention,
And propriety is mere rivalry.

Thus, the depth of benevolence
Is not achieved by using benevolence alone.
The uprightness of righteousness
Is not accomplished by using righteousness alone.
The clarity of ritual and respect
Is not attained by using propriety alone.

To bear all upon the **Dao**,
And unite with its mother—
Then what is displayed is without higher regard,
What is made manifest is without contention.
To use the **nameless**,
Thus names are firmly established.
To use the **formless**,
Thus forms are fully realized.
To keep the mother and preserve its child,
To exalt the root and lift its branches—
Then form and name are both complete,
And perversity does not arise.
Great beauty aligns with Heaven,
And superficiality is not formed.

Thus, the mother must not be abandoned,
The root must not be lost.
Benevolence and righteousness,
Are born from the mother—
Yet they cannot be the mother themselves;
Form and tools,
Are crafted by the artisan—
Yet they cannot be the artisan themselves.
To abandon the mother and use its child,
To forsake the root and follow its branches—
Names then have divisions,
Forms then have limits.
Though great in extent,
There will be gaps;
Though abundant in beauty,
There will be hidden woes.
The **function** lies in action itself—
How could it rest in mere names?

**Chapter 39:** The ancient masters who attained **Oneness**—
*Ancient*, the beginning;
**Oneness**, the first number and the limit of things.
Each recognizes **Oneness** in its own thing,
The principle by which it rules.
All things gain this **Oneness** to complete,
Once complete, they merge to dwell within.
To dwell within is to lose their mother.

Thus, they all split, decay, exhaust, and perish.

Heaven gains **Oneness** and becomes clear,
Earth gains **Oneness** and becomes settled,
The **spirit** gains **Oneness** and becomes agile,
The **grains** gain **Oneness** and become full,
All things gain **Oneness** and come to life,
And the **sovereigns** gain **Oneness** to rule the world with sincerity.

Their attainment—
Each gains **Oneness** to achieve clarity, settlement, agility, life, and sincerity.

Heaven cannot maintain clarity without **Oneness**,
Or it would fear splitting—
*Clarity is achieved through **Oneness**, not by using clarity to achieve clarity.*
To hold **Oneness** is to never lose clarity,
To use clarity is to fear splitting.
Thus, **Oneness** is the mother of **function**,
And must not be abandoned.

Therefore, all avoid using their **function**,
For fear of losing their root.

Earth cannot maintain settlement without **Oneness**,
Or it would fear decay,
The **spirit** cannot maintain agility without **Oneness**,
Or it would fear exhaustion,
The **grains** cannot maintain fullness without **Oneness**,
Or it would fear depletion,
All things cannot maintain life without **Oneness**,
Or it would fear destruction,
And the **sovereigns** cannot maintain noble elevation without **Oneness**,
Or it would fear decline—
Thus, nobility lies in humility as its root,
And elevation lies in lowliness as its foundation.

Therefore, the **sovereigns** call themselves lone and humble,
Without the abundance of grains—
Is this not humility as their root?
Is it not so?

Thus, though fame may be attained,
It is without true praise—
Not desiring to shine like jade,
Or be rough like stone.
Clarity cannot be valued for its clarity alone,
Fullness cannot be multiplied alone—
Nobility lies in its mother,
Yet the mother has no noble form.
Nobility is achieved by humility as its root,
Elevation by lowliness as its foundation—
Thus, though fame may be attained,
It is without true praise.

Jade and stone shine and are rough,
Their substance exhausted in form—
Thus, they are not desired.

chunks.translated_text:
The foundation of elevation lies in lowliness as its root,
Nobility in humility as its source,
Use in emptiness as its substance—
This is its reversal.

When movement knows its emptiness,
Then all things are harmonized.

Thus it is said: *Reversal is the Dao’s movement.*
Weakness is the Dao’s function.

The soft and the weak are universally harmonized,
Beyond exhaustive measure.

All things under heaven are born of being,
Yet being is born of non-being.

All things under heaven take being as their life,
Yet the origin of being lies in non-being.

To preserve being fully,
One must return to non-being.

**Chapter 41:**
The superior person hears the Dao and diligently practices it—
This is resolve.
The middle person hears the Dao and holds it uncertainly,
The inferior person hears the Dao and laughs at it—
If they do not laugh, it is not the Dao.

Thus it is said:
*Establish* (as in *upright*) speech with being—
*Establish* means *to set upright*.
Clarify the Dao as if in darkness,
Shine without dazzling.
Advance the Dao as if retreating,
Put yourself last and yet lead,
Put yourself outside and yet endure.
Level the Dao as if uneven—
*Uneven*, like the soil within.
The great leveling of the Dao follows things’ nature,
Not forcing uniformity to carve them—
Its leveling is unseen,
Thus it returns as if uneven, like soil within.

The highest virtue is like a valley—
Not cherishing its virtue,
Holding nothing in reserve.
The greatest brightness is like a stain—
Knowing its brightness,
Yet guarding its darkness,
Only then attaining true brightness.
Ample virtue seems insufficient—
Ample virtue is not full,
Boundless and formless,
Unfillable.

Establish virtue as if lazy—
*Lazy*, like a match.
To establish virtue is to follow things’ natural course,
Neither forcing nor applying,
Thus it seems lazy and unmatched.
True substance seems false—
True substance does not flaunt its truth,
Thus it seems false.
The greatest square has no corners—
Square yet not rigid,
Thus it has no corners.
Great vessels take long to form—
Great vessels formed,
The world does not hold them complete.
Thus they must take long to form.

Great music is rare in sound—
Hearing it, one does not hear—
Called *rare*, a sound one cannot hear.
Sound implies division,
Division implies it is not *gong* but *shang*—
Division cannot govern all,
Thus sound is not great music.
Great forms are shapeless—
Form implies division,
Division means not temperate but extreme,
Not extreme but cold,
Thus forms with shape are not great forms.

The Dao is hidden, nameless.

Only the Dao
Is good at lending and completing.
All these virtues
Are what the Dao completes.
In form, it becomes great form,
Yet great form is shapeless.
In sound, it becomes great sound,
Yet great sound is rare in hearing.
Things are completed by it,
Yet their completion is unseen,
Thus it is hidden and nameless.

*Lending* is not merely supplying what is lacking—
A single loan suffices to perpetuate its virtue,
Thus it is called *good at lending*.
*Completing* does not require the artificer’s craft—
Without things, it yet fulfills their form,
Thus it is called *good at completing*.

**Chapter 42:**
The Dao gives birth to One,
One gives birth to Two,
Two gives birth to Three,
Three gives birth to all things.

All things bear yin and embrace yang,
And through their harmonizing *qi* achieve balance.
What people detest
Are the lonely, humble, and unfilled—
Yet kings and dukes take them as their titles.

Thus some things are diminished to benefit,
Others are benefited to diminish.
All things, myriad forms,
Yet their return is to One.
How does one attain this One?
It arises from non-being.

From non-being comes One,
And One may be called non-being.
Already calling it One,
How could one avoid speaking of it?
Speaking of it as One,
How could it not be Two?
Having One and Two,
Then Three is born.
From non-being’s being,
Numbers end here—
Beyond this lies no Dao’s flow.

Thus I know the master of all things’ birth,
Though myriad forms they bear,
Their harmonizing *qi* is One.
The common people have hearts,
Diverse lands, varied customs—
Yet those who attain One
Are the kings and dukes.
Taking One as master,
How could One be abandoned?
The more one adds, the farther one strays,
Diminishing brings it near,
Diminishing to exhaustion,
Only then attaining its extreme.

Already calling it One,
Yet still reaching Three—
How much more so if its origin is not One,
And the Dao could be approached?

Diminishing to benefit—
This is no empty saying.
What people teach,
I also teach—
Not forcing others to follow me,
Yet using natural principle,
Upholding its highest truth:
Conforming brings fortune,
Defying brings calamity.
Thus when people teach,
Defying brings their own calamity—
Just as I teach people not to defy.

The forceful and rigid do not meet a good end.
I will take this as my teacher.
The forceful and rigid
Will not meet a good end.
If people teach as forceful and rigid,
Then it is as I teach people not to be forceful and rigid.
Shall I raise the forceful and rigid’s failure to teach?
If it is said that conforming to my teaching brings fortune,
Then those who defy my teaching
Are precisely those who can serve as my teacher.

**Chapter 43:**
The softest under heaven
Overcomes the hardest under heaven—

chunks.original_text: 气无所不入，水无所不出於经。 无有入无间，吾是以知无为之有益。 虚无柔弱，无所不通。 无有不可穷，至柔不可折。 以此推之，故知无为之有益也。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之。 四十四章 名与身孰亲？ 尚名好高，其身又疏。 身与货孰多？ 贪货无厌，其身必少。 得与亡孰病？ 得多利而亡其身，何者为病也？ 是故甚爱必大费，多藏必厚亡。 甚爱不与物通，多藏不与物散。 求之者多，攻之者众，为物所病，故大费厚亡也。 知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 四十五章 大成若缺，其用不弊； 随物而成，不为一象，故若缺也。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 大盈充足，随物而兴，无所爱矜，故若冲也。 大直若屈， 随物而直，直不在一#2，故若屈也。 大巧若拙， 大巧因自然以成器，不造为异端，故若拙也。 大辩若讷。 大辩因物而言，己无所造，故若讷也。 躁胜寒，静胜热，清静为天下正。 躁罢然后胜寒，静无为以胜热，以此推之，则清静为天下正也。 静则全物之真，躁则犯物之性，故唯清静乃得如上诸大也。 四十六章 天下有道，却走马以粪； 天下有道，知足知止，无求於外，各修其内而已，故却走马以治田粪也。 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 贪欲无厌，不修其内，各求於外，故戎马生於郊也。 祸莫大於不知足，咎莫大於欲得，故知足之足，常足矣。 四十七章 不出户，知天下； 不窥牖，见天道。 事有宗而物有主，途虽殊而同归也，虑虽百而其致一也。 道有大常，理有大致，执古之道，可以御今。 虽处於今，可以知古始，故不出户窥牖而可知也。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 无在於一，而求之於众也。 道视之不可见，听之不可闻，搏之不可得，如其知之，不须出户。 若其不知，出愈远愈迷也。 是以圣人不行而知，不见而名， 得物之致，故虽不行，而虑可知也。 识物之宗，故虽不见，而是非之理可得而名也。 不为而成。 明物之性，因之而已。 故虽不为，而使之成矣。 四十八章 为学日益， 务欲进其所能，益其所习。 为道日损。 务欲反虚无也。 损之又损，以至於无为，无为而无不为。 有为则有所失，故无为乃无所不为也。 取天下常以无事， 动常因也。 及其有事， 自己造也。 不足以取天下。 失统本也。 四十九章 圣人无常心，以百姓心为心。 动常因也。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之， 各因其用，则善不失也。 德善。 无弃人也。 信者吾信之，不信者吾亦信之，德信。 圣人在天下歙歙，为天下浑其心，百姓皆注其耳目， 各用聪明。 圣人皆孩之。 皆使和而无欲，如婴兄也。 夫天地设位，圣人成能，人谋鬼谋，百姓与能者。 能者与之，资者取之，能大则大，资贵则贵，物有其宗，事有其主。 如此则可冕旒充目而不惧於欺，黈纩塞耳而无戚於慢，又何为劳一身之聪明，以察百姓之情哉。 夫以明察物，物亦竞以其明应之。 以不信察物，物亦竞以不信应之。 夫天下之心不必同，其所应不敢异，则莫肯用其情矣。 甚矣，害之大也，莫大於用其明矣。 夫在智则人与之讼，在力则人与之争。 智不出於人，而立乎讼地则穷矣； 力不出於人，而立乎争地则危矣。 未有能使人无用其智力乎己者也，如此则己以一敌人，而人以千万敌己也。 若乃多其法纲，烦其刑罚，塞其径路，攻其幽宅，则万物失其自然，百姓丧其手足。

**Chapter 44:**
Qi permeates everywhere without obstruction,
Water flows through everything without hindrance—
This is the Dao of the *jing* (經).
Without obstruction, there is no gap—
Thus I know the benefit of *wuwei* (無為).

The emptiness of *wu* (虚),
The weakness of *ruo* (柔弱),
Yet nothing they cannot traverse.
There is nothing they cannot exhaust—
The most yielding cannot be bent.
By this, I know the benefit of *wuwei*.

The teaching of the unsaid,
The benefit of *wuwei*—
Few under heaven can attain it.

**Chapter 45:**
The greatest completion seems incomplete,
Yet its use never fails;
It shapes itself with things,
Yet does not conform to a single form—
Thus it seems incomplete.

The greatest fullness seems void,
Yet its use is inexhaustible.
When fullness is complete,
It rises and falls with things,
And cherishes nothing—
Thus it seems void.

The greatest straightness seems crooked,
Yet it follows things to be straight—
Straightness is not confined to one thing—
Thus it seems crooked.

The greatest skill seems clumsy,
Yet the greatest skill shapes tools through natural principle,
Without contriving artificiality—
Thus it seems clumsy.

The greatest eloquence seems stammering.
Yet the greatest eloquence arises from things,
Without personal fabrication—
Thus it seems stammering.

Agitation conquers cold,
Stillness conquers heat—
Yet tranquility is the fundamental standard of the world.

Agitation, after its excess,
Then conquers cold;
Stillness, through *wuwei*,
Conquers heat—
By this, I know tranquility is the fundamental standard of the world.

Tranquility preserves the true nature of all things,
Agitation violates the nature of things—
Thus only through tranquility can one attain the above greatness.

**Chapter 46:**
When the Dao prevails under heaven,
Warhorses are turned into dung for the fields;
When the Dao prevails under heaven,
People know sufficiency, know cessation,
And seek nothing from beyond—
Each cultivates their own inner self—
Thus warhorses are turned into dung for the fields.

When the Dao does not prevail under heaven,
Warhorses breed in the suburbs.
Greed is insatiable,
They do not cultivate their inner selves,
Each seeks from beyond—
Thus warhorses breed in the suburbs.

No calamity is greater than not knowing sufficiency,
No blame is greater than desiring more—
Thus, sufficiency in sufficiency,
Is always sufficient.

**Chapter 47:**
Without stepping outside the door,
One knows the affairs of the world;
Without peering through the window,
One sees the Dao of things.

Affairs have their roots, things have their masters—
Though paths differ, they share the same return;
Though thoughts are myriad, their intent is singular.

The Dao has its great constancy,
Principle has its great conclusion—
Clinging to ancient Dao,
One can govern the present.

Though dwelling in the present,
One can know the ancient origins—
Thus one need not step outside the door or peer through the window to know.

The farther one goes,
The less one knows.
Do not fixate on one thing,
Yet seek in the multitude.

The Dao cannot be seen,
Cannot be heard,
Cannot be grasped—
If one knows it,
There is no need to step outside the door.

If one does not know it,
The farther one goes, the more confused one becomes.

Thus the Sage does not act yet knows,
Does not see yet names—
Attaining the conclusion of things,
Thus though not acting, one’s thoughts can be known.

Discerning the root of things,
Thus though not seeing, one can obtain the logic of right and wrong to name.

Completion without action.
Understanding the nature of things,
Following them—
Thus though not acting, one can make them complete.

**Chapter 48:**
To study learning is to daily increase,
Always striving to advance one’s abilities,
To increase one’s practice.

To study the Dao is to daily decrease,
Always striving to return to emptiness.

Decrease again and again,
Until reaching *wuwei*—
*Wuwei* is yet to do nothing,
Yet nothing it cannot do.

Action leads to loss—
Thus *wuwei* is to lose nothing.

To take the world is to always do so without interference,
Movement is always in accordance with nature.

When interference arises,
It is self-made.
This is insufficient to take the world—
It is to lose the root of governance.

**Chapter 49:**
The Sage has no fixed heart,
Taking the hearts of the people as their own.
Movement is always in accordance with nature.

The virtuous, I treat as virtuous,
The non-virtuous, I also treat as virtuous—
Virtue is thus not lost.
The trustworthy, I trust,
The untrustworthy, I also trust—
Trust is thus established.

The Sage, amidst the world,
Unifies the hearts of the people—
All fixate their ears and eyes,
Each using their own cleverness.

The Sage treats them all as children,
Making them harmonious and without desire,
Like newborn infants.

The heavens and earth set their positions,
The Sage completes their abilities—
Human schemes, ghostly schemes,
All are the abilities of the people.

Abilities are given to them,
Resources are taken by them—
Abilities are great, they become great;
Resources are noble, they become noble—
Things have their roots, affairs have their masters.

Thus one can wear the crown and sash,
Fill their eyes with ornaments,
Yet not fear deceit;
Stuff their ears with coarse cloth,
Yet not grieve from insult—
Why labor one’s own cleverness
To discern the emotions of the people?

If one uses cleverness to discern things,
Things will also vie with their cleverness in response.
If one uses distrust to discern things,
Things will also vie with their distrust in response.

The hearts of the world are not necessarily the same,
Yet if their responses dare not differ,
None will dare to use their own cleverness.

Great indeed is the harm of cleverness—
None greater than using one’s cleverness.

If one’s cleverness does not surpass others,
Yet stands in the realm of contention—
It will reach its limits;
If one’s strength does not surpass others,
Yet stands in the realm of struggle—
It will be in peril.

None can make others refrain from using their cleverness or strength against you—
Thus you confront one with your own,
While others confront you with thousands and ten-thousands.

If one multiplies laws and penalties,
Blocks paths and attacks hidden dwellings,
Then all things lose their natural course,
And the people abandon their hands and feet.

The birds are in chaos above,
The fish are in chaos below—
Thus the Sage, regarding the world,
**shēsè** *[1]* his heart, with no fixed master.
He acts with a **húnxīn** *[2]* for the world,
His intent nowhere directed, his will nowhere attached.

He discerns nothing—
Why should the people avoid him?
He demands nothing—
Why should the people obey him?
With no avoidance and no compliance,
None dare fail to use their own **qíng** *[3]*.

When people act without constraint,
They abandon what they can do to do what they cannot,
They abandon what they excel at to do what they lack.

Thus, those who speak say what they know,
Those who act do what they are able—
The people all focus their ears and eyes upon their own affairs,
And I simply nurture them like children.

**Chapter Fifty:**
Life emerges from death,
The realm of life, the realm of death.
Those who cling to life alone—thirteen in ten *[4]*
Those who cling to death alone—thirteen in ten,
And those who live yet are drawn into the realm of death—thirteen in ten.

Why is this so?
Because of the excess of life’s vitality.

It is said: One who masters life well,
Walks on land yet meets no **rìhú** *[5]* (rhinoceros and tigers),
Enters battle yet is not struck by weapons or blades.
The **rì** *[6]* has no place to thrust its horn,
The **hú** has no place to strike with its claws,
Weapons have no place to lodge their edges.

Why is this so?
Because there is no realm of death.

「十有三，犹云十分有三分。
Taking thirteen in ten,
It is as if saying ten parts with three fractions.

取其生道，全生之极，十分有三耳。
Taking the Dao of life,
Preserving life to its utmost—
Ten parts with three fractions.

取死之道，全死之极，十分亦有三耳。
Taking the Dao of death,
Preserving death to its utmost—
Ten parts with three fractions as well.

而民生生之厚，更之无生之地焉。
Yet the people’s excess of life’s vitality
Drives them to the realm where life ceases.

善摄生者，无以生为生，故无死地也。
Those who master life well,
Do not cling to life for life—
Thus, there is no realm of death.

器之害者，莫甚乎戈兵。
The greatest harm of weapons
Is none more severe than spears and blades.

兽之害者，莫甚乎兕虎。
The greatest harm of beasts
Is none more severe than rhinoceros and tigers.

而令兵戈无所容其锋刃，虎兕无所措其爪角，
Yet when spears and blades have no place to lodge their edges,
And rhinoceros and tigers no place to strike with claws and horns,

斯诚不以欲累其身者也，何死地之有乎？
This is truly one who does not burden himself with desires—
How could there be a realm of death?

夫蚖蟺以渊为浅，而凿穴其中；
The *yǎnwù* (salamander and tortoise) *[7]*
Treat the depths as shallow,
And dig their holes within.

鹰鹯以山为卑，而增巢其上。
The *yīngdiāo* (eagle and falcon) *[8]*
Treat the mountains as low,
And build their nests upon them.

矰缴不能及，网罟不能到，
Their snares cannot reach,
Their nets cannot ensnare—

可谓处於无死地矣。
One may say they dwell in the realm of no death.

然而卒以甘饵，乃入於无生之地，
Yet in the end, with sweet bait,
They enter the realm where life ceases—

岂非生生之厚乎？
Is this not the excess of life’s vitality?

故物苟不以求离其本，不以欲渝其真，
Thus, if things do not seek to depart from their root,
Nor do they corrupt their true nature through desire,

虽入军而不害，陆行而不可犯也。
Even in battle, they are unharmed,
And walking on land, they cannot be assailed.

赤子之可则而贵，信矣。」

---

**Chapter Fifty-One:**
The Dao gives birth to life,
Virtue nurtures and sustains it,
Things take their form from it,
And circumstances bring them to fruition.

Life is born, then nurtured,
Nurtured, then formed,
Formed, then brought to fruition.
How does it give birth?
The Dao.

How does it nurture?
Virtue.

How does it take form?
Things themselves.

How does it reach fruition?
Circumstances.

Only through the Dao,
Thus things can take form without material.
Only through circumstances,
Thus things can reach fruition without material.

All that is born and all that is accomplished
Have their origins.
If they have origins,
Then all originate from the Dao.

Thus, when pushed to its extreme,
It is also the utmost Dao.

Follow their origins,
And each finds its proper name.

Therefore, all things honor the Dao
And revere virtue.

The Dao is what things originate from,
Virtue is what they attain.
Attaining through origin,
Thus it is said: *"Not attained, it is lost."*

Revering it brings harm,
Not revering it is noble.

The Dao’s reverence,
Virtue’s nobility—
None command them, yet they arise naturally.

Life gives birth, yet does not possess,
Acts, yet does not claim.
Acting, yet not possessing—
Growing, yet not controlling,
This is called the **Xuan德** *(Xuan Virtue)* *[9]*.

Virtue exists, yet its master is unknown,
Emerging from the depths of obscurity—
Thus it is called the **Xuan德** *(Xuan Virtue)*.

---

**Chapter Fifty-Two:**
The world has its beginning,
And this beginning is the world’s mother.
If one masters the beginning,
Then one masters nurturing and sustaining it.

Thus, the world has a beginning,
And this beginning can be the world’s mother.

Having known its mother,
One may also know its offspring;
Having known its offspring,
One returns and guards its mother—
Thus, it will never perish.

The mother is the root,
The offspring are the branches.
Attaining the root to know the branches,
Not abandoning the root to chase the branches.

Block its **fuì** *(mouth/opening)* *[10]*,
Close its **mén** *(gate/door)* *[11]*.

The **fuì** is where desires originate,
The **mén** is where desires follow.

Thus, one’s whole life is not laborious;
Having no desires, one is perpetually at ease—
Thus, one’s whole life is not laborious.

Open its **fuì**,
Accomplish its affairs—
One’s whole life will never be saved.

Not questioning its source while accomplishing its affairs,
Thus, even one’s whole life will never be saved.

Seeing the small as clarity,
Guarding the soft as strength.

The merit of governance lies not in grandeur.
Seeing the great as unclear,
Seeing the small as clarity.

Guarding strength is not strength,
Guarding softness is strength.

Using its **guāng** *(radiance/splendor)* *[12]*,
Displaying the Dao to dispel the people’s confusion,
Returning to its own clarity.

Not seeing clearly—
This is the obscurity of perception.

chunks.original_text: 无遗身殃，是谓习常。 道之常也。 五十三章 使我介然有知，行於大道，唯施是畏。 言若使我可介然有知，行大道於天下，唯施为之是畏也。 大道甚夷，而民好径。 言大道荡然正平，而民犹尚合之而不由，好从邪径，况复施为以塞大道之中乎？ 故曰大道甚夷，而民好径。 朝甚除， 朝，宫室也。 除，絜好也。 田甚芜，仓甚虚。 朝甚除，则田甚芜，仓甚虚。 设一而众害生也。 服文彩，带利剑，厌饮食，财货有余，是谓盗夸，非道也哉。 凡物不以其道得之，则皆邪也，邪则盗也。 夸而不以其道得之，窃位也。 故举非道以明，非道则皆盗夸也。 五十四章 善建不拔， 固其根而后营其末，故不拔也。 善抱者不脱， 不贪於多，齐其所能，故不脱也。 子孙以祭祀不辍。 子孙传此道以祭祀，则不辍也。 修之於身，其德乃真； 修之於家，其德乃余； 以身及人也。 修之身则真，修之家则有余。 修之不废，所施转大。 修之於乡，其德乃长； 修之於国，其德乃丰； 修之於天下，其德乃普。 故以身观身，以家观家，以乡观乡，以国观国， 彼皆然也。 以天下观天下。 以天下百姓心，观天下之道也。 天下之道逆顺吉凶，亦皆如人之道也。 吾何以知天下然哉？ 以此。 此，上之所云也。 言吾何以得知天下乎，察己以知之，不求於外也。 所谓不出户，以知天下者也。 五十五章 含德之厚，比於赤子，蜂虿虺蛇不螫，猛兽不据，攫鸟不搏。 赤子无求无欲，不犯众物，故毒虫之物无犯之人也。 含德之厚者，不犯於物，故无物以损其全也。 骨弱筋柔而握固， 以柔弱之故，故握能周固。 未知牝牡之合而全作， 作，长也。 无物以损其身，故能全长也。 言含德之厚者，无物可以损其德，渝其真，柔弱不争而不摧折，皆若此也。 精之至也。 终日号而不嘎， 无争欲之心，故终日出声而不嘎也。 和之至也。 知和曰常， 物以和为常，故知和则得常也。 知常曰明， 不皦不昧，不温不凉，此常也。 无形不可得而见曰明也。 益生曰祥， 生不可益，益之则夭也。 心使气曰强。 心宜无有，使气则强。 物壮则老，谓之不道，不道早已。 五十六章 知者不言， 因自然也。 言者不知。 造事端也。 塞其兑，闭其门，挫其锐， 含守质也。 解其分， 除争原也。 和其光， 无所特显，则物无偏争也。 同其尘， 无所特贱，则物无偏耻也。 是谓玄同。 故不可得而亲，不可得而疏； 可得而亲，则可得而疏也。 不可得而利，不可得而害； 可得而利，则可得而害也。 不可得而贵，不可得而贱， 可得而贵，则可得而贱也。 故为天下贵。 无物可以加之也。 五十七章 以正治国，以奇用兵，以无事取天下。 以道治国则国平，以正治国，则奇正起也，以无事则能取天下也。 上章云，其取天下者，常以无事。 及其有事，又不足以取天下也。 故以正治国，则不足以取天下，而以奇用兵也。 夫以道治国，崇本以息末，以正治国，立辟以攻末。 本不立而末浅，民无所及，故必至於奇用兵也。 吾何以知其然哉？ 以此。

「To avoid harm to oneself is called the habit of constancy—
This is the constancy of the **Dao/Way**.

Chapter 53: *If I could stand firm with knowledge,*
*And walk the **Dao/Way** in its entirety,*
*Only **shī** *(施, "bestowal/imposition")* would I fear.*

*If I could stand firm with knowledge,*
*And walk the **Dao/Way** throughout the world,*
*Only bestowal would I fear to impose.*

*The **Dao/Way** is exceedingly smooth and even,*
*Yet the people prefer narrow paths.*
*The **Dao/Way** is vast and unobstructed,*
*Yet the people cling to shortcuts and evils—*
*How much more so when one imposes bestowal,*
*To block the **Dao/Way**’s true course?*
*Thus it is said:*
*The **Dao/Way** is exceedingly smooth and even,*
*Yet the people prefer narrow paths.*

*The court is exceedingly pristine,*
*The palace halls are spotless.*
*The fields are overgrown with weeds,*
*The granaries are empty.*
*When the court is exceedingly pristine,*
*The fields grow wild,*
*The granaries stand void.*
*Thus, one’s actions bring harm to the multitude.*

*Wearing ornate attire,*
*Bearing sharp blades,*
*Feasting on delicacies,*
*Hoarding wealth beyond need—*
*This is called **dào kuā** *(盗夸, "robbery and ostentation")*,*
*Not the **Dao/Way** indeed.*

*All things, if gained not through their proper **Dao/Way**,*
*Are but crookedness—*
*Crookedness is robbery.*
*Ostentation, if not gained through their proper **Dao/Way**,*
*Is usurpation.*
*Thus, to enumerate what is not the **Dao/Way***
*Is to clarify robbery and ostentation.*

Chapter 54: *The well-built does not topple,*
*For it grounds its roots before nurturing its branches,*
*Thus it does not topple.*
*The well-embracing does not slip,*
*Not greedy for excess,*
*Balancing what it can sustain,*
*Thus it does not slip.*
*One’s descendants continue the rites of sacrifice,*
*If they pass down this **Dao/Way** to perform sacrifices,*
*Then the rites will not cease.*

*Cultivating it in oneself,*
*Its **virtue/power** *(德)* becomes true;*
*Cultivating it in the family,*
*Its **virtue/power** overflows;*
*Thus, it extends from oneself to others.*
*Cultivate it in the body, and it is true;*
*Cultivate it in the home, and it abounds.*
*If cultivation does not falter,*
*The bestowal grows ever greater.*
*Cultivating it in the village,*
*Its **virtue/power** becomes enduring;*
*Cultivating it in the state,*
*Its **virtue/power** becomes abundant;*
*Cultivating it throughout the world,*
*Its **virtue/power** becomes universal.*
*Thus, to observe oneself through oneself,*
*To observe the family through the family,*
*To observe the village through the village,*
*To observe the state through the state—*
*All these follow the same principle.*
*To observe the world through the world,*
*With the hearts of the world’s people,*
*To discern the **Dao/Way** of the world.*
*The **Dao/Way** of the world—*
*Its fortune and calamity,*
*Its joy and sorrow—*
*All follow the **Dao/Way** of humanity.*

*How do I know the world’s constancy?*
*By this.*
*This refers to the teachings above.*
*If one asks how I know the world,*
*It is by examining oneself,*
*Not by seeking knowledge from without.*
*This is what is meant by*
*"Knowing the world without leaving one’s door."*

Chapter 55: *The depth of **virtue/power** *(德)* is like that of a newborn babe,*
*Where bees, wasps, centipedes, and snakes do not sting,*
*Where fierce beasts do not seize,*
*Where birds of prey do not clutch.*
*The newborn babe has no desires, no cravings,*
*And does not offend against all things,*
*Thus venomous creatures do not harm it.*
*Those with deep **virtue/power***
*Do not offend against things,*
*Thus nothing can harm their completeness.*

*Though bones are frail and sinews soft,*
*Yet its grasp is firm.*
*Because of its softness and frailty,*
*Its hold is all the more unyielding.*
*Though it knows not the union of male and female,*
*Yet it grows fully.*
*Fully—meaning long in life.*
*Nothing harms its body,*
*Thus it grows fully and long.*

*Those with deep **virtue/power***
*Are not harmed by things,*
*Nor does their truth falter,*
*For softness and frailty do not contend,*
*Yet are never crushed or broken.*
*This is the utmost **harmony** *(和).*

*Crying all day without hoarseness,*
*It has no contentious or desiring heart,*
*Thus it cries all day without hoarseness.*

*Perfect **harmony** is perfect constancy,*
*For all things find constancy in **harmony**,*
*Thus knowing **harmony** brings constancy.*
*Knowing constancy is clarity,*
*Neither dim nor bright,*
*Neither warm nor cold—*
*This is constancy.*
*That which has no form yet cannot be seen is called clarity.*

*Excessive nurturing brings misfortune,*
*Nurturing cannot benefit life—*
*To nurture is to hasten its decline.*
*The heart that directs **qi** is called strength.*
*The heart should have no interference,*
*Yet to direct **qi** is to force strength.*
*When things are over-nurtured, they age prematurely,*
*This is called unnatural—*
*Unnatural brings early decay.*

Chapter 56: *The wise do not speak,*
*For they follow nature.*
*Those who speak are not wise,*
*For they create the origins of affairs.*

*To block its **fuì** *(兑, "radiance/response"),*
*To close its **mén** *(门, "gate/opening"),*
*To blunt its sharpness,*
*Is to hoard and guard its essence.*

*To dissolve its divisions,*
*Is to remove the roots of contention.*
*To harmonize its **guāng** *(光, radiance/splendor),*
*To display nothing in particular,*
*Then things will have no partial strife.*
*To blend with its dust,*
*To hold no particular lowliness,*
*Then things will have no partial shame.*

*This is called **Xuán Tóng** *(玄同, "mysterious unity").*
*Thus, it cannot be grasped as near,*
*Nor can it be grasped as distant;*
*If it can be grasped as near,*
*Then it can be grasped as distant.*
*It cannot be grasped for gain,*
*Nor can it be grasped for harm;*
*If it can be grasped for gain,*
*Then it can be grasped for harm.*
*It cannot be grasped as noble,*
*Nor can it be grasped as base;*
*If it can be grasped as noble,*
*Then it can be grasped as base.*

*Thus, it is held in highest esteem by the world.*
*Nothing can be added to it.*

Chapter 57: *To govern the state with uprightness,*
*To employ the **qí** *(奇, "unconventional/strategic")* in warfare,*
*To take the world with non-action.*

*To govern the state with the **Dao/Way** is to exalt its foundation,*
*Thus the people rest—*
*To govern with uprightness,*
*Then the **qí** and the **zhèng** *(正, "upright")* arise,*
*And to take the world with non-action*
*Is indeed possible.*
*The previous chapter states:*
*"Those who take the world*
*Always act with non-action."*
*When they have affairs,*
*Yet still lack the means to take the world,*
*Thus it is said:*
*"To govern the state with uprightness,*
*Then one cannot take the world,*
*Yet one must employ the **qí** in warfare."*

*To govern the state with the **Dao/Way***
*Exalts the foundation to restrain excess,*
*Yet to govern with uprightness*
*Establishes distinctions to attack what is extraneous.*
*If the foundation is not exalted,*
*And the excess is shallow,*
*The people have nothing to reach,*
*Thus one must resort to employing the **qí** in warfare.*

*How do I know this to be so?*
*By this.»

chunks.original_text: 天下多忌讳，而民弥贫； 民多利器，国家滋昏； 利器，凡所以利己之器也。 民强则国家弱。 人多技巧，奇物滋起； 民多智慧则巧伪生，巧伪生则邪事起。 法令滋彰，盗贼多有。 立正欲以息邪，而奇兵用。 多忌讳欲以耻贫，而民弥贫。 利器欲以强国者也，而国愈昏。 多皆舍本以治末，故以致此也。 故圣人云：我无为而民自化，我好静而民自正，我无事而民自富，我无欲而民自朴。 上之所欲，民从之速也。 我之所欲，唯无欲，而民亦无欲而自朴也。 此四者，崇本以息末也。 五十八章 其政闷闷，其民淳淳； 言善治政者，无形无名，无事无正可举，闷闷然卒至於大治，故曰其政闷闷也。 其民无所争竞，宽大淳淳，故曰其民淳淳也。 其政察察，其民缺缺。 立刑名，明赏罚，以检奸伪，故曰其政察察#3也。 殊类分析，民奸争竞，故曰其民缺缺。 祸兮，福之所倚； 福兮，祸之所伏。 孰知其极？ 其无正。 言谁知善治之极乎，唯无可正举，无可形名，闷闷然而天下大化，是其极也。 正复为奇， 以正治国，则便复以奇用兵矣，故曰正复为奇。 善复为妖， 立善以和万物，则便复有妖之患也。 人之迷，其日固久。 言人之迷惑失道固久矣，不可便正善治以责。 是以圣人方而不割， 以方导物，舍去其邪。 不以方割物，所谓大方无隅。 廉而不剧， 康，清康也。 剧，伤也。 以清康清民，令去其邪，令去其污，不以清康刿伤於物也。 直而不肆， 以直导物，令去其僻，而不以直激沸於物也，所谓直若屈也。 光而不惧。 以光鉴其所以迷，不以光照求其隐匿也，所谓明道若昧也。 此皆崇本以息末，不攻而使复之也。 道德真经注卷之三竟

The world abounds in **taboos and prohibitions** *(忌讳, "avoidances and restrictions")*, yet the people grow ever poorer;
The people possess many **sharp implements** *(利器, "tools of advantage")*, yet the state grows ever more **corrupt and decadent** *(滋昏, "increasingly chaotic")*.
Sharp implements are all those tools by which one profits oneself.
When the people grow strong, the state grows weak.

When men are numerous in **crafts and cunning** *(技巧, "skills and stratagems")*, strange things proliferate;
When the people abound in **wisdom and insight** *(智慧)*, **deceit and artifice** *(巧伪, "clever falsity")* arise,
And when deceit and artifice arise, **wicked deeds** *(邪事, "deviant matters")* follow.
When laws and decrees grow **ostentatious and explicit** *(滋彰)*, thieves and robbers multiply.

To establish uprightness and **restrain the wicked** *(息邪, "halt the deviant")*, yet strange warfare is employed.
To abound in taboos and prohibitions, desiring to **shame poverty** *(耻贫, "disgrace impoverishment")*, yet the people grow ever poorer.
To possess sharp implements, desiring to **strengthen the state** *(强国, "fortify the realm")*, yet the state grows ever more chaotic.
All these seek to **discard the root to govern the branches** *(舍本以治末, "abandon the foundation to manage the extremities")*,
Thus leading to these consequences.

Therefore, the **Sage** *(圣人)* says:
*"I practice non-action, yet the people transform themselves;
I love tranquility, yet the people become upright;
I have no affairs, yet the people grow rich;
I have no desires, yet the people return to simplicity."*
What the ruler desires, the people hasten to follow.
What I desire, is only **non-desire** *(无欲, "lack of desire")*,
Yet the people also lack desire and naturally return to simplicity.

These four principles are to **exalt the foundation and restrain the extremities** *(崇本以息末)*,
To **revert without assault** *(不攻而使复之, "return without confrontation")*.

Its governance is **obscure and unassuming** *(闷闷, "dim and dim")*, its people are **pure and unadulterated** *(淳淳, "simple and simple")*.
The **skilled ruler** *(善治政者)* holds no form, no name,
No affairs, no uprightness to be cited—
Dim and dim, yet ultimately reaching **great harmony** *(大治, "grand order")*,
Thus it is said: *"Its governance is dim and dim."*

Its people have nothing to **contend or vie** *(争竞, "strive and compete")*,
Wide and generous, simple and unadulterated—
Thus it is said: *"Its people are simple and simple."*

Its governance is **scrutinous and meticulous** *(察察, "examining and examining")*,
Its people are **deficient and lacking** *(缺缺, "wanting and wanting")*.
To **establish legal punishments and names** *(立刑名, "set punishments and titles")*,
To **clarify rewards and punishments** *(明赏罚, "illuminate rewards and penalties")*,
To **restrain deceit and artifice** *(检奸伪, "inspect deceit and falsity")*—
Thus it is said: *"Its governance is examining and examining."*

Distinctions are **partitioned and analyzed** *(殊类分析, "differences classified and dissected")*,
The people grow deceitful and vie—
Thus it is said: *"Its people are wanting and wanting."*

**Calamity** *(祸)*, ah! It leans upon **fortune** *(福)*;
**Fortune**, ah! It harbors **calamity** *(祸)*.
Who knows their **limit** *(极, "extreme")*?
It is **non-action** *(无正, "lack of uprightness")*.

Who knows the **extreme of good governance** *(善治之极)*?
Only that which cannot be cited as uprightness,
Cannot be named as form—
Dim and dim, yet the world naturally transforms—
This is its extreme.

**Uprightness** *(正)* again becomes **strange** *(奇)*;
To govern with uprightness, one must then employ strange warfare—
Thus it is said: *"Uprightness again becomes strange."*

**Goodness** *(善)* again becomes **evil** *(妖)*;
To establish goodness and **harmonize all things** *(和万物, "conciliate myriad beings")*,
Yet then **evil** *(妖)* arises as a **calamity** *(患)*.

The **delusion of men** *(人之迷)* is indeed long.
Who knows the **extreme of good governance** *(善治之极)*?
Only that which cannot be cited as uprightness,
Cannot be named as form—
Dim and dim, yet the world naturally transforms—
This is its extreme.

**The Sage** *(圣人)* is **square yet does not cut** *(方而不割)*,
Guiding things with **rectitude** *(方, "squareness")*,
Discarding their **deviance** *(邪, "deviant")*.
Not cutting things with **rectitude**—
This is called: *"The great rectitude has no corners."*

**Moderate yet not harsh** *(廉而不剧)*,
Comfortable, **clear and moderate** *(清康, "pure and tranquil")*.
Harsh, **injury** *(剧, "excessive")*—
To **cleanse and moderate** *(清康)* the people,
To **purify and moderate** *(清民, "clarify the populace")*,
To **remove their deviance** *(去其邪)*,
To **remove their filth** *(去其污)*—
Yet not to **severely harm** *(刿伤, "maim and injure")* with cleansing and moderation.

**Straightforward yet not domineering** *(直而不肆)*,
Guiding things with **straightness** *(直, "directness")*,
To **remove their eccentricity** *(去其僻, "eliminate their crookedness")*,
Yet not to **provoke unrest** *(激沸, "agitate and boil")* with straightness—
This is called: *"Directness is like bending."*

**Bright yet not intimidating** *(光而不惧)*,
Illuminating their **delusion** *(迷, "bewilderment")* with **radiance** *(光, "luminosity")*,
Yet not to **expose their hidden faults** *(求其隐匿, "demand their concealments")* with brightness—
This is called: *"Clarifying the Dao/Way is like obscurity."*

All these are to **exalt the foundation and restrain the extremities** *(崇本以息末)*,
To **revert without assault** *(不攻而使复之)*.
**Dao/Way and Virtue Classic** *(道德真经, "The Classic of the Dao and Virtue")* **commentary** *(注)* **volume three** *(卷之三)* **ends** *(竟).*

**Chapter 59: Governing People and Serving Heaven, Nothing Exceeds Frugality**

Frugality *(啬, "frugality")* is the greatest.
Nothing exceeds *(#1莫若, "nothing surpasses")*—
That is, frugality *(啬, "frugality")* is the farmer *(农夫, "husbandman")*.
The farmer’s cultivation of the fields *(治田, "governing the fields")* seeks to eliminate their **diversity** *(殊类, "varied types")* and return them to **uniformity** *(齐一, "harmonized unity")*.
To preserve their **natural state** *(自然, "spontaneity")* without **forcing their growth** *(急其荒病, "urging their barrenness")*,
To remove the causes of their **barrenness** *(荒病, "withering ailments")*—
This is to **align above with Heaven’s mandate** *(上承天命, "upwardly honor Heaven’s decree")* and **soothe below the people** *(下绥百姓, "downwardly pacify the populace")*,
Nothing surpasses this.

Only frugality *(啬, "frugality")* is called **early service** *(早服, "early governance")*.
**Early service** *(早服, "early governance")*—
That is, **constancy** *(常, "permanent principle")*.
**Early service** *(早服, "early governance")* is called **heavily accumulating virtue** *(重积德, "profoundly amassing virtue")*.
Only through **profoundly amassing virtue** *(重积德, "profoundly amassing virtue")*—
Not seeking **sharp and swift results** *(不欲锐速, "not desiring sharp speed")*—
Then one can **make constancy endure** *(乃能使早服其常, "thus enable early governance to persist")*,
Hence it is said: *Only through profoundly amassing virtue can one achieve early service.*

**Profoundly amassing virtue** *(重积德, "profoundly amassing virtue")* means **nothing is unconquerable** *(无不克, "no resistance remains")*,
**Nothing is unconquerable** *(无不克, "no resistance remains")*—
Then **none know its limits** *(莫知其极, "none fathom its extent")*.
The **Dao/Way** *(道, "Dao")* is **boundless** *(无穷, "endless")*.
**None know its limits** *(莫知其极, "none fathom its extent")*—
This is how one **may possess a state** *(可以有国, "can attain a realm")*.
If one **possesses a state** *(有国, "attains a realm")* with **limited virtue** *(有穷, "bounded virtue")*,
It is **not truly able to possess a state** *(非能有国也, "not indeed capable of attaining a realm")*.
The **foundation of possessing a state** *(有国之母, "root of attaining a realm")*—
This is how one **may endure long** *(可以长久, "can persist long-term")*.
The **reason a state is stable** *(国之所以安, "how a realm stands firm")*—
Is called its **foundation** *(谓之母, "its root")*.
**Profoundly amassing virtue** *(重积德, "profoundly amassing virtue")*—
This is to **seek only its roots** *(是唯图其根, "merely cultivate its foundation")*,
Then **tend to its extremities** *(然后营末, "afterward nurture its branches")*,
Only then does one **achieve its end** *(乃得其终也, "thus attain its fulfillment")*.
This is called: *The **Dao/Way of deep roots and firm foundations** *(深根固柢, "deep-rooted and firmly established")*, **long life and enduring vision** *(长生久视, "longevity and lasting insight").*

**Chapter 60: Governing a Great State, Like Cooking a Small Fish**

Governing a great state *(治大国, "governing a great realm")*—
Is like cooking a small fish *(若烹小鲜, "as if stewing a tiny fish")*.
**Not to disturb** *(不扰也, "not to agitate")*.
**Agitation** *(躁, "restlessness")* brings **many calamities** *(多害, "abundant harm")*,
**Calmness** *(静, "tranquility")* preserves **truth** *(全真, "whole integrity")*.
Thus, the greater the state *(其国弥大, "the more expansive the realm")*,
The more tranquil its ruler *(而其主弥静, "the more serene its sovereign")*,
Only then can one **broadly win the hearts of the people** *(然后乃能广得众心矣, "thus widely secure the people’s loyalty")*.

If one **rules the world with the Dao/Way** *(以道莅天下, "governs the world through the Dao")*,
Its **spirits** *(其鬼, "its numinous forces")* are **not numinous** *(不神, "not revered")*.
To govern a great state like cooking a small fish *(治大国则若烹小鲜, "governing a great realm as if stewing a tiny fish")*—
If one **rules the world with the Dao/Way** *(以道莅天下, "governs the world through the Dao")*,
Then its **spirits** *(其鬼, "its numinous forces")* are **not numinous** *(不神, "not revered")*.
Not that its **spirits** *(其鬼, "its numinous forces")* are **not numinous** *(不神, "not revered")*—
But that their **numinosity** *(其神, "their reverence")* does **not harm people** *(不伤人, "not injure mortals")*.
**Numinosity** *(神, "reverence")* does **not harm spontaneity** *(不害自然也, "not violate spontaneity")*.
Things **abide by spontaneity** *(物守自然, "creatures adhere to spontaneity")*,
Then **numinosity** *(神, "reverence")* has **nothing to add** *(无所加, "no place to impose")*.
**Numinosity** *(神, "reverence")* has **nothing to add** *(无所加, "no place to impose")*—
Then **none know numinosity as numinous** *(则不知神之为神也, "none recognize reverence as reverence")*.
Not that its **numinosity** *(其神, "their reverence")* does **not harm people** *(不伤人, "not injure mortals")*—
The **Sage** *(圣人, "Sage")* also does **not harm people** *(亦不伤人, "also does not injure mortals")*.
When the **Dao/Way is harmonized** *(道洽, "the Dao is complete")*,
Then **numinosity** *(神, "reverence")* does **not harm people** *(不伤人, "not injure mortals")*—
Then **none know numinosity as numinous** *(则不知神之为神也, "none recognize reverence as reverence")*.
When the **Dao/Way is harmonized** *(道洽, "the Dao is complete")*—
The **Sage** *(圣人, "Sage")* also does **not harm people** *(亦不伤人, "also does not injure mortals")*—
Then **none know the Sage as Sage** *(则亦不知圣人之为圣也, "none recognize the Sage as Sage")*.
It is said: *Not only do they not know numinosity as numinous,
They also do not know the Sage as Sage.*

Those who **rely on the net of coercion** *(恃威网, "lean on the web of authority")* to **command things** *(以使物者, "direct creatures")*—
This is the **decline of governance** *(治之衰也, "waning of rule")*.
To **make them unaware of numinosity and sainthood** *(使不知神圣之为神圣, "cause them to not recognize reverence and sainthood as such")*—
This is the **ultimate of the Dao/Way** *(道之极也, "apex of the Dao")*.
The **two** *(两, "the two")*—
**Numinosity** *(神, "reverence")* and **the Sage** *(圣人, "Sage")*—
**Do not harm each other** *(不相伤, "do not injure one another")*,
Thus their **virtue** *(德, "virtue")* **returns in harmony** *(交归焉, "intermingles and returns")*.
**Numinosity** *(神, "reverence")* does **not harm people** *(不伤人, "not injure mortals")*—
The **Sage** *(圣人, "Sage")* also does **not harm people** *(亦不伤人, "also does not injure mortals")*.
The **Sage** *(圣人, "Sage")* does **not harm people** *(不伤人, "not injure mortals")*—
**Numinosity** *(神, "reverence")* also does **not harm people** *(神亦不伤人, "reverence also does not injure mortals")*.
Hence it is said: *The two do not harm each other*—
**Numinosity** and **sainthood** *(神圣, "reverence and sainthood")* **unify with the Dao/Way** *(合道, "converge with the Dao")*,
Their **virtue** *(交归, "intermingling return")* **harmonizes** *(之也, "thus").*

chunks.original_text: 江海居大而处下，则百川流之。 大国居大而处下，则天下流之，故曰大国下流也。 天下之交， 天下所归会也。 天下之牝。 静而不求，物自归之也。 牝常以静胜牡，以静为下。 以其静，故能为下也。 牝，雌也。 雄躁动贪欲，雌常以静，故能胜雄也。 以其静复能为下，故物归之也。 故大国以下小国， 大国以下，犹云以大国下小国。 则取小国； 小国则附之。 小国以下大国，则取大国。 大国纳之也。 故或下以取，或下而取。 言唯修卑下，然后乃各得其所。 大国不过欲兼畜人，小国不过欲入事人。 夫两者各得其所欲，大者宜为下。 小国修下，自全而已，不能令天下归之。 大国修下，则天下归之。 故曰各得其所欲，则大者宜为下也。 六十二章 道者万物之奥， 奥，犹暧也，可得庇荫之辞。 善人之宝， 宝以为用也。 不善人之所保。 保以全也。 美言可以市，尊行可以加人。 言道无所不先，物无有贵於此也。 虽有珍宝璧马，无以匹之。 美言之，则可以夺众货之贾，故曰美言可以市也。 尊行之，则千里之外应之，故曰可以加於人也。 人之不善，何弃之有？ 不善当保道以免放。 故立天子，置三公， 言以尊行道也。 虽有拱璧以先驷马，不如坐进此道。 此道上之所云也。 言故立天子，置三公，尊其位，重其人，所以为道也。 物无有贵於此者，故虽有拱抱宝璧以先驷马而进之，不如坐而进此道也。 古之所以贵比道者，何不日以求得，有罪以免耶？ 故为天下贵。 以求则得求，以免则得免，无所而不施，故为天下贵也。 六十三章 为无为，事无事，味无味。 以无为为居，以不言为教，以恬淡为味，治之极也。 大小多少。 报怨以德。 小怨则不足以报，大怨则天下之所欲诛，顺天下之所同者，德也。 图难於其易，为大於其细。 天下难事必作於易，天下大事必作於细。 是以 圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 夫轻诺必寡信，多易必多难，是以圣人曰犹难之， 以圣人之才，犹尚难於细易，况非圣人之才，而欲忽於此乎？ 故曰犹难之也。 故终无难矣。 六十四章 其安易持，其未兆易谋， 以其安不忘危，持之不忘亡，谋之无功之势，故曰易也。 其脆易浮，其微易散。 虽失无入有，以其微脆之故，未足以兴大功，故易也。 此四者，皆说慎终也。 不可以无之故而不持，不可以微之故而弗散也。 无而弗持，则生有焉； 微而不散，则生大焉。 故虑终之患如始之祸，则无败事。 为之於未有， 谓其安未兆也。 治之於未乱。 谓微脆也。 合抱之木，生於毫末； 九层之台，起於累土； 千里之行，始於足下。 为者败之，执者失之。 当以慎终除微，慎微除乱，而以施为治之，形名执之。 反生事原，巧辟滋作，故败失也。 是以圣人无为，故无败； 无执，故无失。 民之从事，常於几成而败之。 不慎终也。 慎终如始，财无败事。 是以圣人欲不欲，不贵难得之货； 好欲虽微，争尚为之兴。 难得之货虽细，食盗为之起也。 学不学，复众人之所过， 不学而能者，自然也。 喻於不学者#2，过也。 故学不学，以复众人之所过。 以辅万物之自然而不敢为。 六十五章 古之善为道者，非以明民，将以愚之。 明谓多见巧诈，蔽其朴也。 愚谓无知守真，顺自然也。 民之难治，以其智多。
chunks.translated_text:
「People also do not injure mortals, the Sage does not injure mortals—
Then they also do not know the Sage’s way of being the Sage.
It is as though they say not only do they not know Numinosity’s way of being Numinosity,
But they also do not know the Sage’s way of being the Sage.
He who relies on the net of coercion to govern others,
Is the decline of governance.
He who makes others unaware of Numinosity and sainthood as Numinosity and sainthood,
Has reached the Dao’s ultimate expression.
　　Thus it is said: The two do not harm each other,
Hence their virtue intermingles and returns.
Numinosity does not harm people, the Sage also does not harm people—
The Sage does not harm people, Numinosity also does not harm people.
Hence it is said: The two do not harm each other,
Numinosity and sainthood converge with the Dao,
Thus their virtue intermingles and returns.

**Chapter 61: Great States Are the Lowlands**
The great rivers and seas dwell in grandeur yet remain in the lowlands,
And thus all the streams flow toward them.
Great states dwell in grandeur yet remain in the lowlands,
And thus all under Heaven flows toward them—
Hence it is said: *Great states are the lowlands.*

The confluence of all under Heaven,
Is where all under Heaven gathers and meets.
The receptive of all under Heaven,
Is tranquil yet does not seek—
And thus all things return to it.
The receptive always overcomes the assertive through its tranquility,
And the receptive is the lowly.
Because of its tranquility, it can be the lowly.
The receptive is the female—
The assertive is restless, turbulent, and greedy,
The female is always tranquil—
Thus it overcomes the assertive.
Because of its tranquility, it can also be the lowly,
Hence all things return to it.
Therefore, great states humble themselves to the lesser states—
Great states humble themselves, as though they say: *With the great state’s lowliness, the lesser state is taken.*
Then the lesser state attaches to it;
The lesser state humbles itself to the great state,
Then it takes the great state.
The great state receives it—
Thus some humble to take, some humble yet are taken.
It means that only through cultivating humility and lowliness
Can one then attain what each should have.
Great states do not seek to encompass all under Heaven,
Lesser states do not seek to serve the great state.
If both attain what they desire,
Then the greater should humble itself.
Lesser states cultivate lowliness,
And thus they are preserved—
But they cannot make all under Heaven return to them.
Great states cultivate lowliness,
And thus all under Heaven returns to them.
Hence it is said: *If each attains what they desire,*
*Then the greater should humble itself.*

**Chapter 62: The Dao as the Mystery of All Things**
The Dao is the mystery of all things—
Mystery, like warmth, can shelter and shade.
The good person’s treasure—
Treasure is used.
The unworthy person’s refuge—
Refuge is for preservation.
Fine words can be sold,
Venerable conduct can be bestowed upon others.
It means the Dao precedes all things,
And nothing is more precious than this.
Though there be rare treasures and jade discs with fine horses,
Nothing can match it.
Fine words can seize the market price of all goods,
Hence it is said: *Fine words can be sold.*
Venerable conduct can respond even from a thousand miles away,
Hence it is said: *Venerable conduct can be bestowed upon others.*
What of the unworthy—
Why should they be abandoned?
The unworthy should preserve the Dao to avoid being cast aside.
Hence, the Sage establishes the Son of Heaven,
And appoints the Three Exalted Ministers—
It means to honor the Dao’s conduct.
Though there be jade discs held high and fine horses with harnesses,
They are not as good as sitting and offering this Dao.
This is the Dao spoken of above.
It means that the Sage establishes the Son of Heaven,
And appoints the Three Exalted Ministers,
Honors their rank, and esteems their worth—
This is how the Dao is preserved.
Nothing is more precious than this,
Hence though there be jade discs held high and fine horses with harnesses,
They are not as good as sitting and offering this Dao.
The ancients valued those who aligned with the Dao—
Why not say that they sought it daily,
And were freed from blame?
Hence they are honored by all under Heaven.
To seek is to obtain,
To avoid blame is to be free—
The Dao applies everywhere,
Hence they are honored by all under Heaven.

**Chapter 63: The Way of Non-Action**
To act without acting,
To govern without governing,
To savor without savoring—
To reside in non-action,
To teach through silence,
To find flavor in serenity and simplicity,
Is the ultimate of governance.
Great or small, many or few,
Repay resentment with virtue.
Small resentment is not enough to repay,
Great resentment is what all under Heaven would wish to punish—
Following what all under Heaven agree upon,
Is virtue.

Plotting difficulty from ease,
And greatness from smallness—
All under Heaven’s difficult tasks must arise from ease,
All under Heaven’s great tasks must arise from smallness.
Hence the Sage never acts in greatness,
And thus can achieve greatness.
Light promises must be few in trust,
Many easy things must bring many difficulties—
Thus the Sage says: *Even this is difficult,*
For the Sage’s talent still finds difficulty in small and easy matters,
How much more so for those who are not the Sage’s talent,
Yet wish to neglect this?
Hence it is said: *Even this is difficult.*
Thus there will never be difficulty.

**Chapter 64: The Art of Preserving the End**
Its stability is easily maintained,
Its beginnings are easily planned—
Because of its stability, one does not forget peril,
Maintaining it does not forget ruin,
Planning it without effort or strain,
Hence it is said: *easily.*
Its frailty is easily floated upon,
Its subtlety is easily dispersed—
Though it may be lost, no one will take it,
Because of its frailty and subtlety,
It is not sufficient to accomplish great deeds,
Hence it is said: *easily.*
These four sayings all discuss guarding the end.
One cannot neglect what is without maintaining it,
Cannot neglect what is subtle because it will disperse.
Without maintaining what is not, it will generate what is;
Without dispersing what is subtle, it will generate what is great.
Hence, consider the end’s calamity like the beginning’s ruin,
And there will be no failed undertakings.
Act before there is what to act upon—
It means its stability and unseen beginnings.
Govern before there is disorder—
It means its frailty and subtlety.
A tree thick enough to embrace,
Grows from a tiny sprout;
A nine-tiered tower,
Rises from piled earth;
A journey of a thousand miles,
Begins beneath one’s feet.
The doer brings ruin,
The grasper brings loss.
One should guard the end to eliminate frailty,
Guard frailty to eliminate disorder,
And thus apply non-action as governance,
And non-grasping as non-loss.
This reverses the origin of undertakings,
And cleverly creates what should not be—
Hence ruin and loss.
Thus the Sage acts without acting,
And thus there is no ruin;
Does not grasp,
And thus there is no loss.
The people’s undertakings,
Often fail just as they are about to succeed—
Because they do not guard the end.
Guarding the end like the beginning,
Wealth will not bring ruin.
Thus the Sage desires what he does not desire,
Does not prize what is hard to obtain—
Loves what is easy, though slight,
And strives for what is worth contesting.
What is hard to obtain, though small,
Will give rise to thieves—
Learning without learning,
Against the errors of the multitude—
Those who are learned yet do not learn,
Are naturally so.
It is like those who do not learn#2—
Errors.
Hence learning without learning,
To correct the errors of the multitude,
To assist the self-so of all things
Yet not daring to act.»

chunks.original_text: 多智巧诈，故难治也。 故以智治国，国之贼； 智犹治也。 以智而治国，所以谓之贼者，故谓之智也。 民之难治，以其多智也，当务塞兑闭门，令无知无欲，而以智术动民邪心，既动复以巧术防民之伪。 民知其术，防随而避之，思惟密巧，奸伪益滋，故曰以智治国，国之贼也。 不以智治国，国之福。 知此两者亦稽式。 常知稽式，是谓玄德。 玄德深矣远矣， 稽，同也，今古之所同则不可废。 能知稽式，是谓玄德，玄德深矣，远矣。 与物反矣， 反其真也。 然后乃至大顺。 六十六章
chunks.translated_text:
The cunning and deceitful are many—
Thus the people are hard to govern.
To rule the realm with cleverness,
Is the realm’s ruin—
For cleverness is but governance itself.
When one rules with cleverness,
It is called ruin—
Thus it is called cleverness.
The people are hard to govern
Because their cleverness is excessive.
The proper course is to block the senses,
Close the gates,
And let them be without knowledge,
Without desire—
Yet stir their wicked hearts with clever schemes.
Once stirred, then use subtle arts
To guard against their deceit.
When the people know these arts,
They evade and avoid them,
Plotting in secret, their deceit grows ever more.
Thus it is said:
To rule with cleverness is the realm’s ruin.

Not to rule with cleverness—
This is the realm’s blessing.
To know these two is to grasp the standard.
Ever knowing the standard,
This is called the Mysterious Virtue.
The Mysterious Virtue is profound and vast—
The standard, the same—
What is shared by past and present must not be abandoned.
To know the standard is to grasp the Mysterious Virtue,
Profound and vast—
Returning to its origin,
Restoring its truth—
Then attaining the Great Harmony.
